bibl.title: Letter fragment from Laura Reed Blincoe to Howard A. Kelly, January 30, 1903

div1.p: Blincoe provides recollections of Walter Reed's childhood.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Laura Reed Blincoe to Howard A. Kelly, January 30, 1903
div1.opener:
ans. 1/31/03
Ashland, Va.
January 30th 1903
Dr: Kelly,
Dear sir,
div1.p:
I have just rec'd
from my old home in Farmville, the
old daguerreotype from which was
copied one of the pictures sent to you.
On observing it closely, I think the
original is the better picture of Walter
& thinking perhaps in these days of
improved photography you might
get a better likeness of him I send
it to you. Do not think me presump-
tuous, Dr, when I tell you that I
think this one scene in his
small boy life might interest
you -- these four sons of a country
minister- You can readily see their
plain surroundings- their heads
2
adjusted against an old wood
house- The hand that the oldest
one has around the shoulder of
his little brother, was left on
a battlefield around Sharpsburg
in 1863. The two middle ones
were young Confederate soldiers
& laid down their arms with Gen-
R.E.Lee at Appomattox C.H.
I rec'd your letter by Miss
Latimer several days ago & will
do my best to give you as
accurate an account of Walter's
boyhood as I can obtain & from my
own personal contact with him.
I was twelve years his senior
& married & left my parent's home
when he was nine years old &
hence though on frequent long
visits back to my parents &
3
I say much of him, yet to give
you as good a letter as I could, I
have written to my older brothers
particularly, to send me some
contribution of their own. I have
never written anything except in a
private way & my story I fear, will
have to be in the way of a personal
letter & the truth is, I don't know
how to condense- Hence I will tell
you just here that you may not be
able to use what I shall write &
I will not be at all hurt if you
should not see fit to use it at all.
Again, thanking you most sincerely
for your very great kindness I am
div1.closer:
Yours most respectfully Laura Reed Blincoe Many thanks for
copy of Baltimore Sun. I sent your article
to my Brother living in Kansas.
L.R.B.

div1.p:
whether they would be of any
particular use to Dr: Kelly
as showing the bouyancy of
his spirits under all difficulties
I remember some sweet little
incidents of his life when
a child -- his love & constancy
& good will, for he was an
ideal boy, always full of good
humour & ready for work or play
just as the occasion demanded.
Once when I had been very ill
at my father's home in Bedford --
he came into my room quite
early in the morning & inquired
“Sis, how do you feel this morning”?
To which I replied, “I think I'm
a little better, my darling,” he
immediately clapped his little
hands (he was only ten years old)
together & said, “I had rather
6
heard that sound from your
lips than to have had a check
for $500.00 placed in my hands”!
I thought that was quite a speech
from a small boy & a poor one
at that & I always cherished
it in my heart of hearts- But he
was always doing & saying the
right thing from his babyhood
up to latest act- I was nearly
twelve years his senior -- he was
the youngest of my own mother's
children & always the idol of
all our hearts. The last time I
saw him in life was in Farmville
In 1897- As we stood by our dear
old father I remarked “O, Walter
he just longed to see his dear
boy once more but he said “The
U.S. government owns my boy
& I can't see him when I wish”
7
To which W. replied, “If I had
known his condition no govern-
ment under the sun could have
kept me from my father” Many
other sweet & precious things he
said which will be remembered
as long as my poor old life
lasts- For fifty one years &
more my life has been bound
up in his & now as its sands
are running long -- having just
passed my 63rd birthday,
I know the separation from
him & others gone before will
not be for my long- And I rejoice
at the happy prospect & pray
that the remaining years of my
life may be spent in the fear
& love of God & in good deeds
to those around me. I realize that
you & I have much to live for.
